Speaker: walter neff
Dialogue: PHYLLIS DIETRICHSON BARTON KEYES LOLA DIETRICHSON MR. DIETRICHSON NINO ZACHETTI MR. NORTON MR. JACKSON SAM GORLOPIS

Speaker: night watchman
Dialogue: Hello there, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: night watchman
Dialogue: Working pretty late aren't you, Mr. Neff?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Late enough.

Speaker: night watchman
Dialogue: You look kind of all in at that.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'm fine. Let's ride.

Speaker: night watchman
Dialogue: How's the insurance business, Mr. Neff?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: night watchman
Dialogue: They wouldn't ever sell me any. They say I've got something loose in my heart. I say it's rheumatism.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: night watchman
Dialogue: Twelve.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Office memorandum, Walter Neff to Barton Keyes, Claims Manager. Los Angeles, July 16th, 1938. Dear Keyes: I suppose you'll call this a confession when you hear it. I don't like the word confession. I just want to set you right about one thing you couldn't see, because it was smack up against your nose. You think you're such a hot potato as a claims manager, such a wolf on a phoney claim. Well, maybe you are, Keyes, but let's take a look at this Dietrichson claim, Accident and Double Indemnity. You were pretty good in there for a while, all right. You said it wasn't an accident. Check. You said it wasn't suicide. Check. You said it was murder. Check and double check. You thought you had it cold, all wrapped up in tissue paper, with pink ribbons around it. It was perfect, except that it wasn't, because you made a mistake, just one tiny little mistake. When it came to picking the killer, you picked the wrong guy, if you know what I mean. Want to know who killed Dietrichson? Hold tight to that cheap cigar of yours, Keyes. I killed Dietrichson. Me, Walter Neff, insurance agent, 35 years old, unmarried, no visible scars --  Until a little while ago, that is. Yes, I killed him. I killed him for money -- and a woman -- and I didn't get the money and I didn't get the woman. Pretty, isn't it?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It began last May. About the end of May, it was. I had to run out to Glendale to deliver a policy on some dairy trucks. On the way back I remembered this auto renewal on Los Feliz. So I decided to run over there. It was one of those Calif. Spanish houses everyone was nuts about 10 or 15 years ago. This one must have cost somebody about 30,000 bucks -- that is, if he ever finished paying for it.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: It was mid-afternoon, and it's funny, I can still remember the smell of honeysuckle all along that block. I felt like a million. There was no way in all this world I could have known that murder sometimes can smell like honeysuckle...

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Mr. Dietrichson in?

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: Who wants to see him?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: The name is Neff. Walter Neff.

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: If you're selling something --

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Look, it's Mr. Dietrichson I'd like to talk to, and it's not magazine subscriptions.

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: Listen, Mr. Dietrichson's not in.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How soon do you expect him?

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: He'll be home when he gets here, if that's any help to you.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: What is it, Nettie? Who is it?

Speaker: maid's voice
Dialogue: It's for Mr. Dietrichson.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I'm Mrs. Dietrichson. What is it?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How do you do, Mrs. Dietrichson. I'm Walter Neff, Pacific All-Risk.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Pacific all-what?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Pacific All-Risk Insurance Company. It's about some renewals on the automobiles, Mrs. Dietrichson. I've been trying to contact your husband for the past two weeks. He's never at his office.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Is there anything I can do?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: The insurance ran out on the fifteenth. I'd hate to think of your getting a smashed fender or something while you're not fully covered.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Perhaps I know what you mean, Mr. Neff. I've just been taking a sun bath.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: No pigeons around, I hope... About those policies, Mrs. Dietrichson -- I hate to take up your time --

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: That's all right. If you can wait till I put something on, I'll be right down. Nettie, show Mr. Neff into the living room.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Where would the living room be?

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: In there, but they keep the liquor locked up.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That's okay. I always carry my own keys.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: The living room was still stuffy from last night's cigars. The windows were closed and the sunshine coming in through the Venetian blinds showed up the dust in the air. The furniture was kind of corny and old-fashioned, but it had a comfortable look, as if people really sat in it. On the piano, in couple of fancy frames, were Mr. Dietrichson and Lola, his daughter by his first wife They had a bowl of those little red goldfish on the table behind the davenport, but, to tell you the truth, Keyes, I wasn't a whole lot interested in goldfish right then, nor in auto renewals, nor in Mr. Dietrichson and his daughter Lola. I was thinking about that dame upstairs, and the way she had looked at me, and I wanted to see her again, close, without that silly staircase between us.

Speaker: phyllis' voice
Dialogue: I wasn't long, was I?

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: Not at all, Mrs. Dietrichson.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I hope I've got my face on straight.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It's perfect for my money.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Won't you sit down, Mr. -- Neff is the name, isn't it?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: With two f's, like in Philadelphia. If you know the story.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: What story?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: The Philadelphia story. What are we talking about?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: About the insurance. My husband never tells me anything.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It's on your two cars, the La Salle and the Plymouth.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: We've been handling this insurance for three years for Mr. Dietrichson...  That's a honey of an anklet you're wearing, Mrs. Dietrichson.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: We'd hate to see the policies lapse. Of course, we give him thirty days. That's all we're allowed to give.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I guess he's been too busy down at Long Beach in the oil fields.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Could I catch him home some evening for a few minutes?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I suppose so. But he's never home much before eight.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That would be fine with me.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: You're not connected with the Automobile Club, are you?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: No, the All-Risk, Mrs. Dietrichson. Why?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Somebody from the Automobile Club has been trying to get him. Do they have a better rate?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: If your husband's a member.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: No, he isn't.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Well, he'd have to join the club and pay a membership fee to start with. The Automobile Club is fine. I never knock the other fellow's merchandise, Mrs. Dietrichson, but I can do just as well for you. I have a very attractive policy here. It wouldn't take me two minutes to put it in front of your husband.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: For instance, we're writing a new kind of fifty percent retention feature in the collision coverage.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: You're a smart insurance man, aren't you, Mr. Neff?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I've had eleven years of it.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Doing pretty well?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It's a living.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: You handle just automobile insurance, or all kinds?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: All kinds. Fire, earthquake, theft, public liability, group insurance, industrial stuff and so on right down the line.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Accident insurance?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Accident insurance? Sure, Mrs. Dietrichson.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I wish you'd tell me what's engraved on that anklet.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Just my name.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: As for instance?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Phyllis.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Phyllis. I think I like that.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: But you're not sure?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'd have to drive it around the block a couple of times.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Mr. Neff, why don't you drop by tomorrow evening about eight-thirty. He'll be in then.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: My husband. You were anxious to talk to him weren't you?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure, only I'm getting over it a little. If you know what I mean.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: There's a speed limit in this state, Mr. Neff. Forty-five miles an hour.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How fast was I going, officer?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I'd say about ninety.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Suppose you get down off your motorcycle and give me a ticket.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Suppose I let you off with a warning this time.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Suppose it doesn't take.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Suppose I have to whack you over the knuckles.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Suppose I bust out crying and put my head on your shoulder.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Suppose you try putting it on my husband's shoulder.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That tears it.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Eight-thirty tomorrow evening then, Mrs. Dietrichson.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: That's what I suggested.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Will you be here, too?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I guess so. I usually am.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Same chair, same perfume, same anklet?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I wonder if I know what you mean.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I wonder if you wonder.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: She liked me. I could feel that. The way you feel when the cards are...

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: falling right for you, with a nice little pile of blue and yellow chips in the middle of the table. Only what I didn't know then was that I wasn't playing her. She was playing me -- with a deck of marked cards -- and the stakes weren't any blue and yellow chips. They were dynamite. I went back to the office that afternoon to see if I had any mail. It was the same afternoon you had that Sam Gorlopis on the carpet, that truck driver from Inglewood, remember, Keyes?

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Oh, Mr. Neff, Mr. Keyes wants to see you. He's been yelling for you all afternoon.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Is he sore, or just frothing at the mouth a little? Here, park these for me, sweetheart.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Wise up, Gorlopis. You're not kidding anybody with that line of bull. You're in a jam and you know it.

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: Sez you. All I want is my money.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Sez you. All you're gonna get is the cops.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Come in, Walter. This is Sam Gorlopis from Inglewood.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure, I know Mr. Gorlopis. Wrote a policy on his truck. How are you, Mr. Gorlopis?

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: I ain't so good. My truck burned down.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Yeah, he just planted his big foot on the starter and the whole thing blazed up in his face.

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: And didn't even singe his eyebrows.

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: No sir. Look, mister. I got twenty- six hundred bucks tied up in that truck. I'm insured with this company and I want my money.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: You got a wife, Gorlopis?

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: Sure I got a wife.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: You got kids?

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: Two kids.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: What you got for dinner tonight?

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: We got meat loaf.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: How do you make your meat loaf, Gorlopis?

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: Veal and pork and bread and garlic. Greek style.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: How much garlic?

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: Lotsa garlic, Mr. Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Okay, Gorlopis. Now listen here. Let's say you just came up here to tell me how to make meat loaf. That's all, understand? Because if you came up here to claim on that truck, I'd have to turn you over to the law, Gorlopis, and they'd put you in jail. No wife. No kids --

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: And no meat loaf, Gorlopis!

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: I didn't do nothin'.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: No? Look, Gorlopis. Every month hundreds of claims come to this desk. Some of them are phonies, and I know which ones. How do I know, Gorlopis?  Because my little man tells me.

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: What little man?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: The little man in here.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Every time one of those phonies comes along he ties knots in my stomach. And yours was one of them, Gorlopis. That's how I knew your claim was crooked. So what did I do? I sent a tow car out to your garage this afternoon and they jacked up that burned-out truck of yours. And what did they find, Gorlopis? They found what was left of a pile of shavings.

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: What shavings?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: The ones you soaked with kerosene and dropped a match on.

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: Look, Mr. Keyes, I'm just a poor guy. Maybe I made a mistake.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: That's one way of putting it.

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: I ain't feelin' so good, Mr. Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Sign this and you'll feel fine.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Right there. It's a waiver on your claim.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Now you're an honest man again.

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: But I ain't got no more truck.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Goodbye, Gorlopis.

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: Goodbye, Mr. Keyes.

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: Twenty-six hundred bucks. That's a lot of dough where I live.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: What's the matter, Gorlopis? Don't you know how to open the door? Just put your hand on the knob, turn it to the right, pull it toward you --

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: Like this, Mr. Keyes?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: That's the boy. Now the same thing from the outside.

Speaker: gorlopis
Dialogue: Thank you, Mr. Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: What kind of an outfit is this anyway? Are we an insurance company, or a bunch of dimwitted amateurs, writing a policy on a mugg like that?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Wait a minute, Keyes. I don't rate this beef. I clipped a note to that Gorlopis application to have him thoroughly investigated before we accepted the risk.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: I know you did, Walter. I'm not beefing at you. It's the company. The way they do things. The way they don't do things. The way they'll write anything just to get it down on the sales sheet. And I'm the guy that has to sit here up to my neck in phony claims so they won't throw more money out of the window than they take in at the door.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Okay, turn the record over and let's hear the other side.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: I get darn sick of picking up after a gang of fast-talking salesmen dumb enough to sell life insurance to a guy that sleeps in the same bed with four rattlesnakes. I've had twenty- six years of that, Walter, and I --

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: And you loved every minute of it, Keyes. You love it, only you worry about it too much, you and your little man. You're so darn conscientious you're driving yourself crazy. You wouldn't even say today is Tuesday without you looked at the calendar, and then you would check if it was this year's or last year's calendar, and then you would find out what company printed the calendar, then find out if their calendar checks with the World Almanac's calendar.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: That's enough from you, Walter. Get out of here before I throw my desk at you.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I love you, too.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: I really did, too, you old crab, always yelling your fat head off, always sore at everyone. But behind the cigar ashes on your vest I kind of knew you had a heart as big as a house... Back in my office there was a phone message from Mrs. Dietrichson about the renewals. She didn't want me to come tomorrow evening. She wanted me to come Thursday afternoon at three-thirty instead. I had a lot of stuff lined up for that Thursday afternoon, including a trip down to Santa Monica to see a couple of live prospects about some group insurance. But I kept thinking about Phyllis Dietrichson and the way that anklet of hers cut into her leg.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Aren't you coming in?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'm considering it.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I hope you didn't mind my changing the appointment. Last night wasn't so convenient.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That's okay. I was working on my stamp collection.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I was just fixing some iced tea. Would you like a glass?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Unless you have a bottle of beer that's not working.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: There might be some. I never know what's in the ice box.  Nettie!...

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: About those renewals, Mr. Neff. I talked to my husband about it.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You did?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Yes. He'll renew with you he told me. In fact, I thought he'd be here this afternoon.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: But he's not?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That's terrible.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Nettie!... Nettie!... Oh, I forgot, it's the maid's day off.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Don't bother, Mrs. Dietrichson. I'd like some iced tea very much.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Lemon? Sugar?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Fix it your way.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Seeing it's the maid's day off maybe there's something I can do for you.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Like running the vacuum cleaner.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Fresh.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I used to peddle vacuum cleaners. Not much money but you learn a lot about life.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I didn't think you'd learned it from a correspondence course.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Where did you pick up this tea drinking? You're not English, are you?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: No. Californian. Born right here in Los Angeles.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: They say native Californians all come from Iowa.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I wanted to ask you something, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Make it Walter.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Tell me, Walter, on this insurance -- how much commission do you make?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Twenty percent. Why?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I thought maybe I could throw a little more business your way.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I can always use it.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I was thinking about my husband. I worry a lot about him, down in those oil fields. It's very dangerous.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Not for an executive, is it?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: He doesn't just sit behind a desk. He's right down there with the drilling crews. It's got me worried sick.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You mean a crown block might fall on him some rainy night?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Please don't talk like that.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: But that's the idea.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: The other day a casing line snapped and caught the foreman. He's in the hospital with a broken back.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Bad.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's got me jittery just thinking about it. Suppose something like that happened to my husband?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It could.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Don't you think he ought to have accident insurance?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Uh huh.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: What kind of insurance could he have?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Enough to cover doctors' and hospital bills. Say a hundred and twenty-five a week cash benefit. And he'd rate around fifty thousand capital sum.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Capital sum? What's that?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That's if he got killed. Maybe I shouldn't have said that.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I suppose you have to think of everything in your business.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Mr. Dietrichson would understand. I'm sure I could sell him on the idea of some accident protection. Why don't I talk to him about it.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: You could try. But he's pretty tough going.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: They're all tough at first.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: He's got a lot on his mind. He doesn't want to listen to anything except maybe a baseball game on the radio. Sometimes we sit all evening without saying a word to each other.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sounds pretty dull.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: So I just sit and knit.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Is that what you married him for?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Maybe I like the way his thumbs hold up the wool.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Anytime his thumbs get tired --

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I want to ask you something, Mr. Neff. Could I get an accident policy for him -- without bothering him at all?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How's that again.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: That would make it easier for you, too. You wouldn't even have to talk to him. I have a little allowance of my own. I could pay for it and he needn't know anything about it.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Wait a minute. Why shouldn't he know?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Because I know he doesn't want accident insurance. He's superstitious about it.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: A lot of people are. Funny, isn't it?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: If there was a way to get it like that, all the worry would be over. You see what I mean, Walter?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure. I've got good eyesight. You want him to have the policy without him knowing it. And that means without the insurance company knowing that he doesn't know. That's the set-up, isn't it?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Is there anything wrong with it?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I think it's lovely. And then, some dark wet night, if that crown block fell on him --

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: What crown block?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Only sometimes they have to have a little help. They can't quite make it on their own.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I don't know what you're talking about.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Of course, it doesn't have to be a crown block. It can be a car backing over him, or he can fall out of an upstairs window. Any little thing like that, as long as it's a morgue job.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Are you crazy?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Not that crazy. Goodbye, Mrs. Dietrichson.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Look, baby, you can't get away with it.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Get away with what?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You want to knock him off, don't you, baby.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: That's a horrible thing to say!

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Who'd you think I was, anyway? A guy that walks into a good-looking dame's front parlor and says "Good afternoon, I sell accident insurance on husbands. You got one that's been around too long? Somebody you'd like to turn into a little hard cash? Just give me a smile and I'll help you collect." Boy, what a dope I must look to you!

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I think you're rotten.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I think you're swell. So long as I'm not your husband.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Get out of here.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You bet I will. You bet I'll get out of here, baby. But quick.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: So I let her have it, straight between the eyes. She didn't fool me for a minute, not this time. I knew I had hold of a redhot poker and the time to drop it was before it burned my hand off. I stopped at a drive-in for a bottle of beer, the one I had wanted all along, only I wanted it worse now, to get rid of the sour taste of her iced tea, and everything that went with it. I didn't want to go back to the office, so I dropped by a bowling alley at Third and Western and rolled a few lines to get my mind thinking about something else for a while.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: I didn't feel like eating dinner when I left, and I didn't feel like a show, so I drove home, put the car away and went up to my apartment.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: It had begun to rain outside and I watched it get dark and didn't even turn on the light. That didn't help me either. I was all twisted up inside, and I was still holding on to that red-hot poker. And right then it came over me that I hadn't walked out on anything at all, that the hook was too strong, that this wasn't the end between her and me. It was only the beginning.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: So at eight o'clock the bell would ring and I would know who it was without even having to think, as if it was the most natural thing in the world.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: You forgot your hat this afternoon.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Did I?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Don't you want me to bring it in?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure. Put it on the chair.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How did you know where I live?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's in the phone book.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's raining.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: So it is. Peel off your coat and sit down.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Your husband out?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Long Beach. They're spudding in a new well. He phoned he'd be late. About nine-thirty.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's about time you said you're glad to see me.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I knew you wouldn't leave it like that.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Like it was this afternoon.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I must have said something that gave you a terribly wrong impression. You must surely see that. You must never think anything like that about me, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's not okay. Not if you don't believe me.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What do you want me to do?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I want you to be nice to me. Like the first time you came to the house.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It can't be like the first time. Something has happened.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I know it has. It's happened to us.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That's what I mean.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What's the matter now?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I feel as if he was watching me. Not that he cares about me. Not any more. But he keeps me on a leash. So tight I can't breathe. I'm scared.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What of? He's in Long Beach, isn't he?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I oughtn't to have come.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Maybe you oughtn't.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: You want me to go?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: If you want to.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Right now?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure. Right now.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How were you going to do it?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Do what?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Kill him.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter, for the last time --

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'm crazy about you, baby.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I'm crazy about you, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That perfume on your hair. What's the name of it?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Something French. I bought it down at Ensenada.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: We ought to have some of that pink wine to go with it. The kind that bubbles. But all I have is bourbon.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Bourbon is fine, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Soda?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Plain water, please.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Get a couple of glasses, will you.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You know, about six months ago a guy slipped on the soap in his bathtub and knocked himself cold and drowned. Only he had accident insurance. So they had an autopsy and she didn't get away with it.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Who didn't?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: His wife.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: And there was another case where a guy was found shot and his wife said he was cleaning a gun and his stomach got in the way. All she collected was a three-to-ten stretch in Tehachapi.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Perhaps it was worth it to her.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: See if you can carry this as far as the living room.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's nice here, Walter. Who takes care of it for you?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: A colored woman comes in twice a week.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: You get your own breakfast?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Once in a while I squeeze a grapefruit. The rest I get at the corner drugstore.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It sounds wonderful. Just strangers beside you. You don't know them. You don't hate them. You don't have to sit across the table and smile at him and that daughter of his every morning of your life.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What daughter? Oh, that little girl on the piano.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Yes. Lola. She lives with us. He thinks a lot more of her than he does of me.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Ever think of a divorce?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: He wouldn't give me a divorce.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I suppose because it would cost him money.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: He hasn't got any money. Not since he went into the oil business.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: But he had when you married him?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Yes, he had. And I wanted a home. Why not? But that wasn't the only reason. I was his wife's nurse. She was sick for a long time. When she died, he was all broken up. I pitied him so.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: And now you hate him.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Yes, Walter. He's so mean to me. Every-time I buy a dress or a pair of shoes he yells his head off. He won't let me go anywhere. He keeps me shut up. He's always been mean to me. Even his life insurance all goes to that daughter of his. That Lola.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Nothing for you at all, huh?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: No. And nothing is just what I'm worth to him.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: So you lie awake in the dark and listen to him snore and get ideas.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter, I don't want to kill him. I never did. Not even when he gets drunk and slaps my face.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Only sometimes you wish he was dead.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Perhaps I do.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: And you wish it was an accident, and you had that policy. For fifty thousand dollars. Is that it?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Perhaps that too.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: The other night we drove home from a party. He was drunk again. When we got into the garage he just sat there with his head on the steering wheel and the motor still running. And I thought what it would be like if I didn't switch it off, just closed the garage door and left him there.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'll tell you what it would be like, if you had that accident policy, and tried to pull a monoxide job. We have a guy in our office named Keyes. For him a set-up like that would be just like a slice of rare roast beef. In three minutes he'd know it wasn't an accident. In ten minutes you'd be sitting under the hot lights. In half an hour you'd be signing your name to a confession.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: But Walter, I didn't do it. I'm not going to do it.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Not if there's an insurance company in the picture, baby. So long as you're honest they'll pay you with a smile, but you just try to pull something like that and you'll find out. They know more tricks than a carload of monkeys. And if there's a death mixed up in it, you haven't got a prayer. They'll hang you as sure as ten dimes will buy a dollar, baby.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Just stop thinking about it, will you.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: So we just sat there, and she kept on crying softly, like the rain on the window, and we didn't say anything. Maybe she had stopped thinking about it, but I hadn't. I couldn't. Because it all tied up with something I had been thinking about for years, since long before I ever ran into Phyllis Dietrichson. Because, in this business you can't sleep for trying to figure out the tricks they could pull on you. You're like the guy behind the roulette wheel, watching the customers to make sure they don't crook the house. And then one night, you get to thinking how you could crook the house yourself. And do it smart. Because you've got that wheel right under your hands. And you know every notch in it by heart. And you figure all you need is a plant out in front, a shill to put down the bet. And suddenly the doorbell rings and the whole set-up is right there in the room with you... Look, Keyes, I'm not trying to whitewash myself. I fought it, only maybe I didn't fight it hard enough. The stakes were fifty thousand dollars, but they were the life of a man, too, a man who'd never done me any dirt. Except he was married to a woman he didn't care anything about, and I did...

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I've got to go now, Walter.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Will you call me, Walter?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter!

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I hate him. I loathe going back to him. You believe me, don't you, Walter?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure I believe you.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I can't stand it anymore. What if they did hang me?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You're not going to hang, baby.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's better than going on this way.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: -- you're not going to hang, baby. Not ever. Because you're going to do it the smart way. Because I'm going to help you.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: You!

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Me.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Do you know what you're saying?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure I know what I'm saying.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: We're going to do it together. We're going to do it right. And I'm the guy that knows how.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter, you're hurting me.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: There isn't going to be any slip up. Nothing sloppy. Nothing weak. It's got to be perfect.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You go now.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Call me tomorrow. But not from your house. From a booth. And watch your step. Every single minute. It's got to be perfect, understand. Straight down the line.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Straight down the line.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: The first thing we had to do was fix him up with that accident policy. I knew he wouldn't buy, but all I wanted was his signature on an application. So I had to make him sign without his knowing what he was signing. And I wanted a witness other than Phyllis to hear me give him a sales talk. I was trying to think with your brains, Keyes. I wanted all the answers ready for all the questions you were going to spring as soon as Dietrichson was dead.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: A couple of nights later I went to the house. Everything looked fine, except I didn't like the witness Phyllis had brought in. It was Dietrichson's daughter Lola, and it made me feel a little queer in the belly to have her right there in the room, playing Chinese checkers, as if nothing was going to happen.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I suppose you realize, Mr. Dietrichson, that, not being an employee, you are not covered by the State Compensation Insurance Act. The only way you can protect yourself is by having a personal policy of your own.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: I know all about that. The next thing you'll tell me I need earthquake insurance and lightning insurance and hail insurance.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: If we bought all the insurance they can think up, we'd stay broke paying for it, wouldn't we, honey?

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: What keeps us broke is you going out and buying five hats at a crack. Who needs a hat in California?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I always say insurance is a lot like a hot water bottle. It looks kind of useless and silly hanging on the hook, but when you get that stomach ache in the middle of the night, it comes in mighty handy.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Now you want to sell me a hot water bottle.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Dollar for dollar, accident insurance is the cheapest coverage you can buy, Mr. Dietrichson.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Maybe some other time, Mr. Neff. I had a tough day.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Just as you say, Mr. Dietrichson.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Suppose we just settle that automobile insurance tonight.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure. All we need on that is for you to sign an application for renewal.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Phyllis, do you mind if we don't finish this game? It bores me stiff.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Got some thing better to do?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Yes, I have.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Father, is it all right if I run along now?

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Run along where? Who with?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Just Anne. We're going roller skating.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Anne who?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Anne Matthews.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's not that Nino Zachetti again?

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: It better not be that Zachetti guy. If I ever catch you with that ---

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: It's Anne Matthews, I told you. I also told you we're going roller skating. I'm meeting her at the corner of Vermont and Franklin -- the north- west corner, in case you're interested. And I'm late already. I hope that is all clear. Good night, Father. Good night, Phyllis.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Good night, Miss Dietrichson.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Oh, I'm sorry. Good night, Mr. --

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Neff.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Good night, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Now you're not going to take my car again.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: No thanks. I'd rather be dead.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: A great little fighter for her weight.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: This is where you sign, Mr. Dietrichson.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Sign what?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: The applications for your auto renewals. So you'll be protected until the new policies are issued.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: When will that be?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: In about a week.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Just so I'm covered when I drive up North.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: San Francisco, Mr. Dietrichson?

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Palo Alto.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: He was a Stanford man, Mr. Neff. And he still goes to his class reunion every year.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: What's wrong with that? Can't I have a little fun even once a year?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Great football school, Stanford. Did you play football, Mr. Dietrichson?

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Left guard. Almost made the varsity, too.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: On that bottom line, Mr. Dietrichson.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Both copies, please.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Sign twice, huh?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: One is the agent's copy. I need it for my files.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Files. Duplicates. Triplicates.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: No hurry about the check, Mr. Dietrichson. I can pick it up at your office some morning.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: How much you taking me for?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: One forty-seven fifty, Mr. Dietrichson.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I guess that's enough insurance for one evening, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Plenty.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Good night, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Good night, Mr. Dietrichson. Good night, Mrs. Dietrichson.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Bring me some soda when you come up, Phyllis.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I think you left your hat in the hall.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: All right, Walter?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: He signed it, didn't he?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure he signed it. You saw him.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Watch it, will you.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Listen. That trip to Palo Alto When does he go?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: End of the month.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: He drives, huh?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: He always drives.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Not this time. You're going to make him take the train.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Because it's all worked out for a train.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's all right. Go on, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Look, baby. There's a clause in every accident policy, a little something called double indemnity. The insurance companies put it in as a sort of come-on for the customers. It means they pay double on certain accidents. The kind that almost never happen. Like for instance if a guy got killed on a train, they'd pay a hundred thousand instead of fifty.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: We're hitting it for the limit, baby. That's why it's got to be a train.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's going to be a train, Walter. Just the way you say. Straight down the line.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. Neff. It's me.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Something the matter?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I've been waiting for you.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: For me? What for?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I thought you could let me ride with you, if you're going my way.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Which way would that be?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Down the hill. Down Vermont.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Oh, sure. Vermont and Franklin. North- west corner, wasn't it? Be glad to, Miss Dietrichson.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Roller skating, eh? You like roller skating?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I can take it or leave it.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Only tonight you're leaving it?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Yes, I am. You see, Mr. Neff, I'm having a very tough time at home. My father doesn't understand me and Phyllis hates me.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That does sound tough, all right.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: That's why I have to lie sometimes.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You mean it's not Vermont and Franklin.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: It's Vermont and Franklin all right. Only it's not Anne Matthews. It's Nino Zachetti. You won't tell on me, will you?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'd have to think it over.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Nino's not what my father says at all. He just had bad luck. He was doing pre-med at U.S.C. and working nights as an usher in a theater downtown. He got behind in his credits and flunked out. Then he lost his job for talking back. He's so hot- headed.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That comes expensive, doesn't it?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I guess my father thinks nobody's good enough for his daughter except maybe the guy that owns Standard Oil. Would you like a stick of gum?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Never use it, thanks.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I can't give Nino up. I wish father could see it my way.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It'll straighten out all right, Miss Dietrichson.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I suppose it will sometime.  This is the corner right here, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: There he is. By the bus stop.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: He needs a hair-cut, doesn't he. Look at him. No job, no car, no money, no prospects, no nothing.  I love him.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Nino!

Speaker: lola's voice
Dialogue: Over here, Nino.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: This is Mr. Neff, Nino.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Hello, Nino.

Speaker: zachetti
Dialogue: The name is Zachetti.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Nino. Please. Mr. Neff gave me a ride from the house. I told him all about us.

Speaker: zachetti
Dialogue: Why does he have to get told about us?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: We don't have to worry about Mr. Neff, Nino.

Speaker: zachetti
Dialogue: I'm not doing any worrying. Just don't you broadcast so much.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: What's the matter with you, Nino? He's a friend.

Speaker: zachetti
Dialogue: I don't have any friends. And if I did, I like to pick them myself.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Look, sonny, she needed the ride and I brought her along. Is that anything to get tough about?

Speaker: zachetti
Dialogue: All right, Lola, make up your mind. Are you coming or aren't you?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Of course I'm coming. Don't mind him, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Thanks a lot. You've been very sweet.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: She was a nice kid and maybe he was a little better than he sounded. I kind of hoped so for her sake, but right then it gave me a nasty feeling to be thinking about them at all, with that briefcase right behind my head and her father's application in it. Besides, I had other problems to work out. There were plans to make, and Phyllis had to be in on them...

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: ...but we couldn't be seen together any more and I had told her never to call me from her house and never to call me at my office. So we had picked out a big market on Los Feliz. She was to be there buying stuff every day about eleven o'clock, and I could run into her there. Kind of accidentally on purpose.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Not so loud.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I wanted to talk to you, Walter. Ever since yesterday.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Let me talk first. It's all set. The accident policy came through. I've got it in my pocket. I got his check too. I saw him down in the oil fields. He thought he was paying for the auto insurance. The check's just made out to the company. It could be for anything. But you have to send a check for the auto insurance, see. It's all right that way, because one of the cars is yours.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: But listen, Walter ---

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Quick, open your bag.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Can you get into his safe deposit box?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Yes. We both have keys.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Fine. But don't put the policy in there yet. I'll tell you when. And listen, you never touched it or even saw it, understand?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I'm not a fool.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Okay. When is he taking the train?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter, that's just it. He isn't going.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: That's what I've been trying to tell you. The trip is off.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What's happened?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: That one up there.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: This one?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: I don't see why they always have to put what I want on the top shelf.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Go ahead. I'm listening.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: He had a fall down at the well. He broke his leg. It's in a cast.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That knocks it on the head all right.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: What do we do, Walter?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Nothing. Just wait.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Wait for what?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Until he can take a train. I told you it's got to be a train.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: We can't wait. I can't go on like this.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: We're not going to grab a hammer and do it quick, just to get it over with.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: There are other ways.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Only we're not going to do it other ways.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: But we can't leave it like this. What do you think would happen if he found out about this accident policy?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Plenty. But not as bad as sitting in that death-house.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Don't ever talk like that, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Just don't let's start losing our heads.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's not our heads. It's our nerve we're losing.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: We're going to do it right. That's all I said.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter maybe it's my nerves. It's the waiting that gets me.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It's getting me just as bad, baby. But we've got to wait.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Maybe we have, Walter. Only it's so tough without you. It's like a wall between us.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Good-bye baby. I'm thinking of you every minute.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: After that a full week went by and I didn't see her once. I tried to keep my mind off her and off the whole idea. I kept telling myself that maybe those fates they say watch over you had gotten together and broken his leg to give me a way out. Then it was the fifteenth of June. You may remember that date, Keyes. I do too, only for a very different reason. You came into my office around three in the afternoon...

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Hello, Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: I just came from Norton's office. The semi-annual sales records are out. You're high man, Walter. That's twice in a row. Congratulations.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Thanks. How would you like a cheap drink?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: How would you like a fifty dollar cut in salary?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How would I -- Do I laugh now, or wait until it gets funny?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: I'm serious, Walter. I've been talking to Norton. There's too much stuff piling up on my desk. Too much pressure on my nerves. I spend half the night walking up and down in my bed. I've got to have an assistant. I thought that you --

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Me? Why pick on me?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Because I've got a crazy idea you might be good at the job.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That's crazy all right. I'm a salesman.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Yeah. A peddler, a glad-hander, a back-slapper. You're too good to be a salesman.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Nobody's too good to be a salesman.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Phooey. All you guys do is ring door- bells and dish out a smooth line of monkey talk. What's bothering you is that fifty buck cut, isn't it?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That'd bother anybody.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Look, Walter. The job I'm talking about takes brains and integrity. It takes more guts than there is in fifty salesman. It's the hottest job in the business.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It's still a desk job. I don't want a desk job.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: A desk job. Is that all you can see in it? Just a hard chair to park your pants on from nine to five. Just a pile of papers to shuffle around, and five sharp pencils and a scratch pad to make figures on, with maybe a little doodling on the side. That's not the way I see it, Walter. To me a claims man is a surgeon, and that desk is an operating table, and those pencils are scalpels and bone chisels. And those papers are not just forms and statistics and claims for compensation. They're alive, they're packed with drama, with twisted hopes and crooked dreams. A claims man, Walter, is a doctor and a blood-hound and a cop and a judge and a jury and a father confessor, all in one.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Who? Okay, hold the line.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: And you want to tell me you're not interested. You don't want to work with your brains. All you want to work with is your finger on a door- bell. For a few bucks more a week. There's a dame on your phone.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Walter Neff speaking.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I had to call you, Walter. It's terribly urgent. Are you with somebody?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Of course I am. Can't I call you back... Margie?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter, I've only got a minute. It can't wait. Listen. He's going tonight. On the train. Are you listening, Walter? Walter!

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'm listening. Only make it short... Margie.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: He's on crutches. The doctor says he can go if he's careful. The change will do him good. It's wonderful, Walter. Just the way you wanted it. Only with the crutches it's ever so much better, isn't it?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: One hundred percent better. Hold the line a minute.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Suppose I join you in your office, Keyes --

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: I'll wait. Only tell Margie not to take all day.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Go ahead.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's the ten-fifteen from Glendale. I'm driving him. Is it still that same dark street?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Yeah -- sure.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: The signal is three honks on the horn. Is there anything else?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What color did you pick out?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Color?  Oh, sure. The blue suit, Walter. Navy blue. And the cast on his left leg.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Navy blue. I like that fine.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: This is it, Walter. I'm shaking like a leaf. But it's straight down the line now for both of us. I love you, Walter. Goodbye.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: So long, Margie.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: What's the matter? The dames chasing you again? Or still? Or is it none of my business?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: If I told you it was a customer --

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Margie! I bet she drinks from the bottle. Why don't you settle down and get married, Walter?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Why don't you, for instance?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: I almost did, once. A long time ago.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Look, Keyes, I've got a prospect to call on.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: We even had the church all picked out, the dame and I. She had a white satin dress with flounces on it. And I was on my way to the jewelry store to buy the ring. Then suddenly that little man in here started working on me.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: So you went back and started investigating her. That it?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: And the stuff that came out. She'd been dyeing her hair ever since she was sixteen. And there was a manic- depressive in her family, on her mother's side. And she already had one husband, a professional pool player in Baltimore. And as for her brother --

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I get the general idea. She was a tramp from a long line of tramps.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: All right, I'm going. What am I to say to Norton? How about that job I want you for?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I don't think I want it. Thanks, Keyes, just the same.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Fair enough. Just get this: I picked you for the job, not because I think you're so darn smart, but because I thought maybe you were a shade less dumb than the rest of the outfit. I guess I was all wet. You're not smarter, Walter. You're just a little taller.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: That was it, Keyes, and there was no use kidding myself any more. Those fates I was talking about had only been stalling me off. Now they had thrown the switch. The gears had meshed. The machinery had started to move and nothing could stop it. The time for thinking had all run out. From here on it was a question of following the time table, move by move, just as we had it rehearsed. I wanted my time all accounted for for the rest of the afternoon and up to the last possible moment in the evening. So I arranged to call on a prospect in Pasadena about a public liability bond. When I left the office I put my rate book on the desk as if I had forgotten it. That was part of the alibi.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: I got home about seven and drove right into the garage. This was another item to establish my alibi.

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: Hiya there, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How about a wash job on my heap, Charlie?

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: How soon you want it, Mr. Neff? I got two cars ahead of you.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Anytime you get to it, Charlie. I'm staying in tonight.

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: Okay, Mr. Neff. Be all shined up for you in the morning.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That left front tire looks a little soft. Check it, will you?

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: You bet. Check 'em all round. Always do.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: Up in my apartment I called Lou Schwartz, one of the salesmen that shared my office. He lived in Westwood. That made it a toll call and there'd be a record of it. I told him I had forgotten my rate book and needed some dope on the public liability bond I was figuring. I asked him to call me back. This was another item in my alibi, so that later on I could prove that I had been home.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: I changed into a navy blue suit like Dietrichson was going to wear. Lou Schwartz called me back and gave me a lot of figures...

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: I stuffed a hand towel and a big roll of adhesive tape into my pockets, so I could fake something that looked like a cast on a broken leg... Next I fixed the telephone and the doorbell, so that the cards would fall down if the bells rang. That way I would know there had been a phone call or visitor while I was away. I left the apartment house by the fire stairs and side door. Nobody saw me. It was already getting dark. I took the Vermont Avenue bus to Los Feliz and walked from there up to the Dietrichson house. There was that smell of honeysuckle again, only stronger, now that it was evening.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: Then I was in the garage. His car was backed in, just the way I told Phyllis to have it. It was so still I could hear the ticking of the clock on the dashboard. I kept thinking of the place we had picked out to do it, that dark street on the way to the station, and the three honks on the horn that were to be the signal... About ten minutes later they came down.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: You all right, honey? I'll have the car out in a second.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Take it easy, honey. We've got lots of time.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Just let me do it my own way. Grab that crutch.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: They ought to make these things so they fold up.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Aw, stop squawkin' can't you, Phyllis? No man takes his wife along to a class reunion. That's what class reunions are for.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Mrs. Tucker went along with her husband last year, didn't she.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Yeah, and what happened to her? She sat in the hotel lobby for four days straight. Never even saw the guy until we poured him back on the train.

Speaker: phyllis' voice
Dialogue: All right, honey. Just so long as you have a good time.

Speaker: dietrichson's voice
Dialogue: I won't do much dancing, I can tell you that.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Remember what the doctor said. If you get careless you might end up with a shorter leg.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: So what? I could break the other one and match them up again.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It makes you feel pretty good to get away from me, doesn't it?

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: It's only for four days. I'll be back Monday at the latest.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Don't forget we're having the Hobeys for dinner on Monday.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: The Hobeys? We had them last. They owe us a dinner, don't they?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Maybe they do but I've already asked them for Monday.

Speaker: dietrichson
Dialogue: Well, I don't want to feed the Hobeys.

Speaker: dietrichson's voice
Dialogue: And I don't want to eat at their house either. The food you get there, and that rope he hands out for cigars. Call it off, can't you?

Speaker: dietrichson's voice
Dialogue: What are you doing that for? What the --

Speaker: man
Dialogue: You handle the redcap and the conductor.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Don't worry.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Keep them away from me as much as you can. I don't want to be helped.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I said don't worry, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You start just as soon as the train leaves. At the dairy sign you turn off the highway onto the dirt road. From there it's exactly eight-tenths of a mile to the dump beside the tracks. Remember?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I remember everything.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You'll be there a little ahead of the train. No speeding. You don't want any cops stopping you -- with him in the back.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter, we've been through all that so many times.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: When you turn off the highway, cut all your lights. I'm going to be back on the observation platform. I'll drop off as close to the spot as I can. Wait for the train to pass, then blink your lights twice.

Speaker: redcap
Dialogue: San Francisco train, lady?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Car nine, section eleven. Just my husband going.

Speaker: redcap
Dialogue: Car nine, section eleven. Yessum, this way please.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's all right, thanks. My husband doesn't like to be helped.

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: Car nine, section eleven. The gentleman only. Thank you.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Goodbye, honey. Take awful good care of yourself with that leg.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure, I will. Just you take it easy going home.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I'll miss you, honey.

Speaker: redcap
Dialogue: Section eleven, suh.

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: All aboard!

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Good luck, honey.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Can you make up my berth right away?

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'm going back to the observation car for a smoke.

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: This way, sir. Three cars back.

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: Can I pull a chair out for you?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: No thanks, I'd rather stand.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: You going far?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Palo Alto.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: My name's Jackson. I'm going all the way to Medford. Medford, Oregon. Had a broken arm myself once.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: That darn cast sure itches something fierce, don't it? I thought I'd go crazy with mine.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Palo Alto's a nice little town. You a Stanford man?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Used to be.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: I bet you left something behind. I always do.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: My cigar case. Must have left it in my overcoat back in the section.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Care to roll yourself a cigarette, Mr. --?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Dietrichson. Thanks. I really prefer cigars.  Maybe the porter --

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: I could get your cigars for you. Be glad to, Mr. Dietrichson.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That's darn nice of you. It's car nine, section eleven. If you're sure it's not too much trouble.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Car nine, section eleven. A pleasure.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Okay. This has to go fast. Take his hat and pick up the crutches.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Hang on to that rug. I'll need it.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Let's go. Stay behind me.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Get in. You drive.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Let's go, baby.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: On the way back we went over once more what she was to do at the inquest, if they had one, and about the insurance, when that came up. I was afraid she might go to pieces a little, now that we had done it, but she was perfect. No nerves. Not a tear, not even a blink of the eyes...

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: She dropped me a block from my apartment house.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: What's the matter, Walter. Aren't you going to kiss me?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure, I'm going to kiss you.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: It's straight down the line, isn't it?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I love you, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I love you, baby.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: It was two minutes past eleven as I went up the fire stairs again. Nobody saw me this time either.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: In the apartment I checked the bells. The cards hadn't moved. No calls. No visitors.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: I changed the blue suit. There was one last thing to do. I wanted the garage man to see me again.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You going to need it after all, Mr. Neff? I'm about through.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It's okay, Charlie. Just walking down to the drug store for something to eat. Been working upstairs all evening. My stomach's getting sore at me.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: That was all there was to it. Nothing had slipped, nothing had been overlooked, there was nothing to give us away. And yet, Keyes, as I was walking down the street to the drug store, suddenly it came over me that everything would go wrong. It sounds crazy, Keyes, but it's true, so help me: I couldn't hear my own footsteps. It was the walk of a dead man.

Speaker: colored man
Dialogue: Didn't know anybody was here, Mr. Neff. We ain't cleaned your office yet.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Let it go tonight. I'm busy.

Speaker: colored man
Dialogue: Whatever you say, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That was the longest night I ever lived through, Keyes, and the next day was worse, when the story broke in the papers, and they were talking about it at the office, and the day after that when you started digging into it. I kept my hands in my pockets because I thought they were shaking, and I put on dark glasses so people couldn't see my eyes, and then I took them off again so people wouldn't get to wondering why I wore them. I was trying to hold myself together, but I could feel my nerves pulling me to pieces....

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Come on, Walter. The big boss wants to see us.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That Dietrichson case?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Must be.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Anything wrong?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: The guy's dead, we had him insured and it's going to cost us money. That's always wrong.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What have you got so far?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Autopsy report. No heart failure, no apoplexy, no predisposing medical cause of any kind. He died of a broken neck.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: When is the inquest?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: They had it this morning. His wife and daughter made the identification. The train people and some passengers told how he went through to the observation car.. It was all over in forty-five minutes. Verdict, accidental death.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What do the police figure?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: That he got tangled up in his crutches and fell off the train. They're satisfied. It's not their dough.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: I believe the legal position is now clear, gentlemen. Please stand by. I may need you later.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Come in, Mr. Keyes. You too, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: You find this an uncomfortably warm day Mr. Keyes?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Sorry, Mr. Norton. I didn't know this was formal.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Sit down, gentlemen.  Any new developments?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: I just talked to this Jackson long distance. Up in Medford, Oregon.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Who's Jackson?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: The last guy that saw Dietrichson alive. They were out on the observation platform together talking. Dietrichson wanted a cigar and Jackson went to get Dietrichson's cigar case for him. When he came back to the observation platform, no Dietrichson. Jackson didn't think anything was wrong until a wire caught up with the train at Santa Barbara. They had found Dietrichson's body on the tracks near Burbank.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Very interesting, about the cigar case.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Anything else?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Not much. Dietrichson's secretary says she didn't know anything about the policy. There is a daughter, but all she remembers is Neff talking to her father about accident insurance at their house one night.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I couldn't sell him at first. Mrs. Dietrichson opposed it. He told me he'd think it over. Later on I went down to the oil fields and closed him. He signed the application and gave me his check.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: A fine piece of salesmanship that was, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: There's no sense in pushing Neff around. He's got the best sales record in the office. Are your salesmen supposed to know that the customer is going to fall off a train?

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Fall off a train? Are we sure Dietrichson fell off the train?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: I don't get it.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: You don't, Mr. Keyes? Then what do you think of this case? This policy might cost us a great deal of money. As you know, it contains a double indemnity clause. Just what is your opinion?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: No opinion at all.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Not even a hunch? One of those interesting little hunches of yours?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Nope. Not even a hunch.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: I'm surprised, Mr. Keyes. I've formed a very definite opinion. I think I know -- in fact I know I know what happened to Dietrichson.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: You know you know what?

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: I know it was not an accident.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: What do you say to that?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Me? You've got the ball. Let's see you run with it.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: There's a widespread feeling that just because a man has a large office --

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Yes?... Have her come in, please.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: -- that just because a man has a large office he must be an idiot. I'm having a visitor, if you don't mind.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: No, no. I want you to stay and watch me handle this.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Mrs. Dietrichson.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Thank you very much for coming, Mrs. Dietrichson. I assure you I appreciate it.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: This is Mr. Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: How do you do.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: How do you do.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: And Mr. Neff.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I've met Mr. Neff. How do you do.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Mrs. Dietrichson, I assure you of our sympathy in your bereavement. I hesitated before asking you to come here so soon after your loss.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: But now that you're here I hope you won't mind if I plunge straight into business. You know why we asked you to come, don't you?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: No. All I know is that your secretary made it sound very urgent.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Your husband had an accident policy with this company. Evidently you don't know that, Mrs. Dietrichson.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: No. I remember some talk at the house --

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: -- but he didn't seem to want it.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: He took it out a few days later, Mrs. Dietrichson.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: You'll probably find the policy among his personal effects.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: His safe deposit box hasn't been opened yet. It seems a tax examiner has to be present.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Please, Mrs. Dietrichson, I don't want you to think you are being subjected to any questioning. But there are a few things we should like to know.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: What sort of things?

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: We have the report of the coroner's inquest. Accidental death. We are not entirely satisfied. In fact we are not satisfied at all.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Frankly, Mrs. Dietrichson, we suspect suicide.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Would you like a glass of water?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Mr. Neff.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Had your husband been moody or depressed lately, Mrs. Dietrichson? Did he seem to have financial worries, for instance?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: He was perfectly all right and I don't know of any financial worries.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: There must have been something, Mrs. Dietrichson. Let us examine this so- called accident. First, your husband takes out this policy in absolute secrecy. Why? Because he doesn't want his family to suspect what he intends to do.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Do what?

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Commit suicide. Next, he goes on this trip entirely alone. He has to be alone. He hobbles all the way out to the observation platform, very unlikely with his leg in a cast, unless he has a very strong reason. Once there, he finds he is not alone. There is a man there. What was his name, Keyes?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: His name was Jackson. Probably still is.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Jackson. So your husband gets rid of this Jackson with some flimsy excuse about cigars. And then he is alone. And then he does it. He jumps. Suicide. In which case the company is not liable.  You know that, of course. We could go to court --

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I don't know anything. In fact I don't know why I came here.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: Just a moment, please. I said we could go to court. I didn't say we want to. Not only is it against our practice, but it would involve a great deal of expense, a lot of lawyers, a lot of time, perhaps years.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: So what I want to suggest is a compromise on both sides. A settlement for a certain sum, a part of the policy value --

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Don't bother, Mr. Norton. When I came in here I had no idea you owed me any money. You told me you did. Then you told me you didn't. Now you tell me you want to pay me a part of it, whatever it is. You want to bargain with me, at a time like this. I don't like your insinuations about my husband, Mr. Norton, and I don't like your methods. In fact I don't like you, Mr. Norton. Goodbye, gentlemen.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Nice going, Mr. Norton. You sure carried that ball.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Only you fumbled on the goal line. Then you heaved an illegal forward pass and got thrown for a forty-yard loss. Now you can't pick yourself up because you haven't got a leg to stand on.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: I haven't eh? Let her claim. Let her sue. We can prove it was suicide.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Can we? Mr. Norton, the first thing that hit me was that suicide angle. Only I dropped it in the wastepaper basket just three seconds later. You ought to take a look at the statistics on suicide sometime. You might learn a little something about the insurance business.

Speaker: norton
Dialogue: I was raised in the insurance business, Mr. Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Yeah. In the front office. Come on, you never read an actuarial table in your life. I've got ten volumes on suicide alone. Suicide by race, by color, by occupation, by sex, by seasons of the year, by time of day. Suicide, how committed: by poisons, by fire-arms, by drowning, by leaps. Suicide by poison, subdivided by types of poison, such as corrosive, irritant, systemic, gaseous, narcotic, alkaloid, protein, and so forth. Suicide by leaps, subdivided by leaps from high places, under wheels of trains, under wheels of trucks, under the feet of horses, from steamboats. But Mr. Norton, of all the cases on record there's not one single case of suicide by leap from the rear end of a moving train. And do you know how fast that train was going at the point where the body was found? Fifteen miles an hour. Now how could anybody jump off a slow moving train like that with any kind of expectation that he would kill himself? No soap, Mr. Norton. We're sunk, and we're going to pay through the nose, and you know it. May I have this?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Come on, Walter.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Next time I'll rent a tuxedo.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I could have hugged you right then and there, Keyes, you and your statistics. You were the only one we were really scared of, and instead you were almost playing on our team...

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: That evening when I got home my nerves had eased off. I could feel the ground under my feet again, and it looked like easy going from there on it.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Hello... Hello, baby.... Sure, everything is fine... You were wonderful in Norton's office.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I felt so funny. I wanted to look at you all the time.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How do you think I felt? Where are you, baby?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: At the drug store. Just a block away. Can I come up?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Okay. But be careful. Don't let anybody see you.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Hello, Keyes.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What's on your mind?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: That broken leg. The guy broke his leg.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Talking about Dietrichson. He had accident insurance, didn't he? Then he broke his leg, didn't he?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: So what?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: And he didn't put in a claim. Why didn't he put in a claim? Why?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What the dickens are you driving at?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Walter. There's something wrong. I ate dinner two hours ago. It stuck half way.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: The little man is acting up again. Because there's something wrong with that Dietrichson case.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Because he didn't put in a claim? Maybe he just didn't have time.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Oh maybe he just didn't know he was insured.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: No. That couldn't be it. You delivered the policy to him personally, didn't you, Walter? And you got his check.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure, I did.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Got any bicarbonate of soda?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: No I haven't.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Listen, Walter. I've been living with this little man for twenty-six years. He's never failed me yet. There's got to be something wrong.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Maybe Norton was right. Maybe it was suicide, Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: No. Not suicide.  But not accident either.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What else?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Look. A man takes out an accident policy that is worth a hundred thousand dollars if he is killed on a train. Then, two weeks later, he is killed on a train. And not in a train accident, mind you, but falling off some silly observation car. Do you know what the mathematical probability of that is, Walter? One out of I don't know how many billions. And add to that the broken leg. It just can't be the way it looks, Walter. Something has been worked on us.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Such as what?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Murder?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Don't you have any peppermint or anything?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'm sorry.  Who do you suspect?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Maybe I like to make things easy for myself. But I always tend to suspect the beneficiary.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: The wife?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Yeah. That wide-eyed dame that didn't know anything about anything.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You're crazy, Keyes. She wasn't even on the train.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: I know she wasn't, Walter. I don't claim to know how it was worked, or who worked it, but I know that it was worked.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: I've got to get to a drug store. It feels like a hunk of concrete inside me.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Good night, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Good night, Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: See you at the office in the morning.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: But I'd like to move in on her right now, tonight, if it wasn't for Norton and his stripe-pants ideas about company policy. I'd have the cops after her so quick her head would spin. They'd put her through the wringer, and, brother, what they would squeeze out.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Only you haven't got a single thing to go on, Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Not too much. Twenty-six years experience, all the percentage there is, and this lump of concrete in my stomach.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: No bicarbonate of soda.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: How much does he know?

Speaker: neff
