Dialogue: It's not what he knows. It's those stinking hunches of his.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: But he can't prove anything, can he?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Not if we're careful. Not if we don't see each other for a while.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: For how long a while?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Until all this dies down. You don't know Keyes the way I do. Once he gets his teeth into something he won't let go. He'll investigate you. He'll have you shadowed. He'll watch you every minute from now on. Are you afraid, baby?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Yes, I'm afraid. But not of Keyes. I'm afraid of us. We're not the same any more. We did it so we could be together, but instead of that it's pulling us apart. Isn't it, Walter?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: And you don't really care whether we see each other or not.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Shut up, baby.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Lola Dietrichson. Don't you remember me?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Yes. Of course.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Could I talk to you, just for a few minutes? Somewhere where we can be alone?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure. Come on into my office.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Is it something to do with -- what happened?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Neff. It's about my father's death.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'm terribly sorry, Miss Dietrichson.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Lou, do you mind if I use the office alone for a few minutes?

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: It's all yours, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Won't you sit down?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Mr. Neff, I can't help it, but I have such a strange feeling that there is something queer about my father's death.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Queer? Queer in what way?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I don't know why I should be bothering you with my troubles, except that you knew my father and knew about the insurance he took out. And you were so nice to me that evening in your car.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure. We got along fine, didn't we.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Look at me, Mr. Neff. I'm not crazy. I'm not hysterical. I'm not even crying. But I have the awful feeling that something is wrong, and I had the same feeling once before -- when my mother died.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: When your mother died?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: We were up at Lake Arrowhead. That was six years ago. We had a cabin there. It was winter and very cold and my mother was very sick with pneumonia. She had a nurse with her. There were just the three of us in the cabin. One night I got up and went into my mother's room. She was delirious with fever. All the bed covers were on the floor and the windows were wide open. The nurse wasn't in the room. I ran and covered my mother up as quickly as I could. Just then I heard a door open behind me. The nurse stood there. She didn't say a word, but there was a look in her eyes I'll never forget. Two days later my mother was dead.  Do you know who that nurse was?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: No. Who?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Phyllis. I tried to tell my father, but I was just a kid then and he wouldn't listen to me. Six months later she married him and I kind of talked myself out of the idea that she could have done anything like that. But now it's all back again, now that something has happened to my father, too.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You're not making sense, Miss Dietrichson. Your father fell off a train.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Yes, and two days before he fell off that train what was Phyllis doing? She was in her room in front of a mirror, with a black hat on, and she was pinning a black veil to it, as if she couldn't wait to see how she would look in mourning.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Look. You've had a pretty bad shock. Aren't you just imagining all this?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I caught her eyes in the mirror, and they had that look in them they had before my mother died. That same look.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You don't like your step-mother, do you? Isn't it just because she is your step-mother?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I loathe her. Because she did it. She did it for the money. Only you're not going to pay her, are you, Mr. Neff? She's not going to get away with it this time. I'm going to speak up. I'm going to tell everything I know.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You'd better be careful, saying things like that.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I'm not afraid. You'll see.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to act like this.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: All this that you've been telling me -- who else have you told?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: No one.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How about your step-mother?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Of course not. I'm not living in the house any more. I moved out.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: And you didn't tell that boy-friend of yours? Zachetti.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I'm not seeing him any more. We had a fight.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Where are you living then?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I got myself a little apartment in Hollywood.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Four walls, and you just sit and look at them, huh?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Neff.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: So I took her to dinner that evening at a Mexican joint down on Olvera Street where nobody would see us. I wanted to cheer her up..

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: Next day was Sunday and we went for a ride down to the beach. She had loosened up a bit and she was even laughing... I had to make sure she wouldn't tell that stuff about Phyllis to anybody else. It was dynamite, whether it was true or not. And I had no chance to talk to Phyllis. You were watching her like a hawk, Keyes. I couldn't even phone her for fear you had the wires tapped.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: Monday morning there was a note on my desk that you wanted to see me, Keyes. For a minute I wondered if it could be about Lola. It was worse. Outside your door was the last guy in the world I wanted to see.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Come in. Come in, Walter. I want to ask you something. After all the years we've known each other, do you mind if I make a rather blunt statement?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: About me. Walter, I'm a very great man. This Dietrichson business. It's murder, and murders don't come any neater. As fancy a piece of homicide as anybody ever ran into. Smart and tricky and almost perfect, but --

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: but, I think Papa has it all figured out, figured out and wrapped up in tissue paper with pink ribbons on it.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'm listening.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: You know what? That guy Dietrichson was never on the train.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: He wasn't?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: No, he wasn't, Walter. Look, you can't be sure of killing a man by throwing him off a train that's going fifteen miles an hour. The only way you can be sure is to kill him first and then throw his body on the tracks. That would mean either killing him on the train, or -- and this is where it really gets fancy -- you kill him somewhere else and put him on the tracks. Two possibilities, and I personally buy the second.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You're way ahead of me, Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Look, it was like this. They killed the guy -- the wife and somebody else -- and then the somebody else took the crutches and went on the train as Dietrichson, and then the somebody else jumped off, and then they put the body on the tracks where the train had passed. An impersonation, see. And a cinch to work. Because it was night, very few people were about, they had the crutches to stare at, and they never really looked at the man at all.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It's fancy all right, Keyes. Maybe it's a little too fancy.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Is it? I tell you it fits together like a watch. And now let's see what we have in the way of proof. The only guy that really got a good look at this supposed Dietrichson is sitting right outside my office. I took the trouble to bring him down here from Oregon. Let's see what he has to say.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Come in, Mr. Jackson.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Yes sir, Mr. Keyes. These are fine cigars you smoke.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Two for a quarter.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: That's what I said.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Never mind the cigar, Jackson. Did you study those photographs? What do you say?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Yes, indeed, I studied them thoroughly. Very thoroughly

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Well? Did you make up your mind?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Mr. Keyes, I'm a Medford man. Medford, Oregon. Up in Medford we take our time making up our minds --

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Well you're not in Medford now. I'm in a hurry. Let's have it.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Are these photographs of the late Mr. Dietrichson?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Then my answer is no.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: What do you mean no?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: I mean this is not the man that was on the train.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Will you swear to that?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: I'm a Medford man. Medford, Oregon. And if I say it, I mean it, and if I mean it, of course I'll swear it.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: There you are, Walter. There's your proof.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Oh, Mr. Jackson, this is Mr. Neff, one of our salesmen.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Please to meet you, Mr. Neff. Pleased indeed.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How do you do.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Very fine, thank you. Never was better.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Mr. Jackson, how would you describe the man you saw on that observation platform?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Well, I'm pretty sure he was a younger man, about ten or fifteen years younger than the man in these photographs.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Dietrichson was about fifty, wasn't he, Walter?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Fifty-one, according to the policy.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: The man I saw was nothing like fifty- one years old. Of course, it was pretty dark on that platform and, come to think of it, he tried to keep his back towards me. But I'm positive just the same.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: That's fine, Jackson. Now you understand this matter is strictly confidential. We may need you again down here in Los Angeles, if the case comes to court.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Any time you need me, I'm at your entire disposal, gentlemen. Expenses paid, of course.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Get me Lubin, in the cashier's office.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Ever been in Medford, Mr. Neff?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Never.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Wait a minute. Do you go trout fishing? Maybe I saw you up Klamath Falls way.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Nope. Never fish.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Neff. Neff. I've got it! It's the name. There's a family of Neffs in Corvallis.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: No relation.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Let me see. This man's an automobile dealer in Corvallis. Very reputable man, too, I'm told.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: All right, Mr. Jackson. Suppose you go down to the cashier's office -- room twenty-seven on the eleventh floor. They'll take care of your expense account and your ticket for the train tonight.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Tonight? Tomorrow morning would suit me better. There's a very good osteopath down here I want to see before I leave.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Okay, Mr. Jackson. Just don't put her on the expense account.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Goodbye, gentlemen. A pleasure.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: There it is, Walter. It's beginning to come apart at the seams already. A murder's never perfect. It always comes apart sooner or later. And when two people are involved it's usually sooner. We know the Dietrichson dame is in it, and somebody else. Pretty soon we're going to know who that somebody else is. He'll show. He's got to show. Sometime, somewhere, they've got to meet. Their emotions are all kicked up. Whether it's love or hate doesn't matter. They can't keep away from each other. They think it's twice as safe because there are two of them. But it's not twice as safe. It's ten times twice as dangerous. They've committed a murder and that's not like taking a trolley ride together where each one can get off at a different stop. They're stuck with each other. They've got to ride all the way to the end of the line. And it's a one-way trip, and the last stop is the cemetery.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Have you got one of those?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Let her sue us if she dares. I'll be ready for her -- and that somebody else. They'll be digging their own graves.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Mrs. Dietrichson?... This is Jerry's market. We just got in a shipment of that English soap you were asking about. Will you be coming by this morning?... Thank you, Mrs. Dietrichson.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Hello, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Come closer.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Everything's the matter. Keyes is rejecting your claim. He's sitting back with his mouth watering, waiting for you to sue. He wants you to sue. But you're not going to.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: What's he got to stop me?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: He's got the goods. He's figured out how it was worked. He knows it was somebody else on the train. He's dug up a witness he thinks will prove it.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Prove it how? Listen, if he rejects that claim, I have to sue.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Yeah? And then you're in court and a lot of other things are going to come up. Like, for instance, about you and the first Mrs. Dietrichson.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: What about me and the first Mrs. Dietrichson?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: The way she died. And about that black hat you were trying on -- before you needed a black hat.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter, Lola's been telling you some of her cockeyed stories. She's been seeing you.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I've been seeing her, if you want to know. So she won't yell her head off about what she knows.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Yes, she's been putting on an act for you, crying all over your shoulder, that lying little --

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Keep her out of it. All I'm telling you is we're not going to sue.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Because you don't want the money any more, even if you could get it? Because she's made you feel like a heel all of sudden.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It isn't the money any more. It's our necks now. We're pulling out, understand.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Because of what Keyes can do? You're not fooling me, Walter. It's because of Lola. What you did to her father. You can't take it that she might find out some day.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I said, leave her out of it.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Walter, it's me I'm talking about. I don't want to be left out of it.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Stop saying that. It's just that it hasn't worked out the way we wanted. We can't have the money. We can't go through with it, that's all.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: We have gone through with it, Walter. The tough part is all behind us. We just have to hold on now and not go soft inside, and stick together, close, the way we started out.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Watch it, will you. Someone's coming.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: I loved you, Walter. And I hated him. But I wasn't going to do anything about it, not until I met you. It was you had the plan. I only wanted him dead.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Yeah, and I was the one that fixed him so he was dead. Is that what you're telling me?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Yes. And nobody's pulling out. We went into it together, and we're coming out at the end together. It's straight down the line for both of us, remember.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: Yeah. I remembered all right. Just as I remembered what you had told me, Keyes, about that trolley car ride and how there was no way to get off -- until the end of the line.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Yeah, I remembered it all right. Just as I remembered what you had told me, Keyes, about that trolley car ride, and how there was no way to get off until the end of the line, where the cemetery was. And I got to thinking what cemeteries are for. They're to put dead people in, I guess that was the first time I ever thought about Phyllis that way. Dead, I mean, and how things would be if she was dead. Because the way it was now she had me by the throat. She could hang me higher than a kite any day she felt like it. And there was nothing I could do, except hold my breath and watch that day come closer and closer, and maybe pray a little, if I still knew how to pray... I saw Lola three or four times that week. I guess it sounds crazy, Keyes, after what I had done, but it was only with her that I could relax and let go a little. Then one night we drove up into the hills above Hollywood Bowl...

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Why are you crying?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You won't tell me?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Of course I will, Walter. I wouldn't tell anybody else but you. It's about Nino.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Zachetti? What about him?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: They killed my father together. He and Phyllis. He helped her do it. I know he did.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What makes you say that?

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I've been following him. He's at her house, night after night. It was Phyllis and him all the time. Maybe he was going with me just for a blind. And the night of the murder --

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You promised not to talk that way any more.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: -- he was supposed to pick me up after a lecture at U.C.L.A. -- but he never showed up. He said he was sick. Sick! He couldn't show up, because the train was leaving with my father on it.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: Maybe I'm just crazy. Maybe it's all just in my mind.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sure, it's all in your mind.

Speaker: lola
Dialogue: I only wish it was, Walter, because I still love him.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: Zachetti. That's funny. Phyllis and Zachetti. What was he doing up at her house? I couldn't figure that one out I tried to make sense out of it and got nowhere. But the real brain-twister came the next day. You sprang it on me, Keyes, after office hours, when you caught me down in the lobby of the building.

Speaker: keyes' voice
Dialogue: Oh, Walter, just a minute.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Hello, Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Hang onto your hat, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Nothing much. The Dietrichson case just busted wide open.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: How do you mean?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: The guy showed. That's how.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: The somebody else?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Yeah. The guy that did it with her.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: No kidding?

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: She's filed suit against us, and it's okay by me. When we get into that courtroom I'll tear them apart, both of them. Come on -- I'll buy you a martini.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: No thanks, Keyes.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: With two olives.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I've got to get a shave and a shoeshine. I've got a date.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: Margie. I still bet she drinks from the bottle.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: They give you matches when they sell you cigars, Keyes. All you have to do is ask for them.

Speaker: keyes
Dialogue: I don't like them. They always explode in my pockets. So long, Walter.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: You sure had me worried, Keyes. I didn't know if you were playing cat- and-mouse with me, whether you knew all along I was the somebody else. That's what I had to find out, and I thought I knew where to look...

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Twelve.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: Upstairs, the last of the people were just leaving.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: I made sure nobody saw me go into your office.

Speaker: keyes' voice
Dialogue: Memo to Mr. Norton. Confidential. Dietrichson File. With regard to your proposal to put Walter Neff under surveillance, I disagree absolutely. I have investigated his movements on the night of the crime, and he is definitely placed in his apartment from 7:15 P.M. on. In addition to this, I have known Neff intimately for eleven years, and I personally vouch for him, without reservation...

Speaker: keyes' voice
Dialogue: ...Furthermore, no connection whatsoever has been established between Walter Neff and Mrs. Phyllis Dietrichson, whereas I am now able to report that such a connection has been established between her and another man. This man has been observed to visit the Dietrichson home on the night of July 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th and 13th. We have succeeded in identifying him as one Nino Zachetti, former medical student, aged twenty-eight, residing at Lilac Court Apartments 1228 N. La Brea Avenue. We have checked Zachetti's movements on the night of the crime and have found that they cannot be accounted for. I am preparing a more detailed report for your consideration and it is my belief that we already have sufficient evidence against Zachetti and Mrs. Dietrichson to justify police action. I strongly urge that this whole matter be turned over to the office of the District Attorney. Respectfully, Barton Keyes.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Phyllis? Walter. I've got to see you... Tonight... Yes, it has to be tonight... How's eleven o'clock? Don't worry about Keyes. He's satisfied... Leave the door on the latch and put the lights out. No, nobody's watching the house... I told you Keyes is satisfied. It's just for the neighbors... That's what I said. Yeah. Eleven o'clock. Goodbye, baby.

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: I guess I don't have to tell you what I was going to do at eleven o'clock, Keyes. For the first time I saw a way to get clear of the whole mess I was in, and of Phyllis, too, all at the same time. Yeah, that's what I thought. But what I didn't know was that she was all set for me. That she had outsmarted me again, just like she always had...

Speaker: neff's voice
Dialogue: She was all set and waiting for me. It could have been something in my voice when I called her up that tipped her off. And it could have been that she had the idea already. And an idea wasn't the only thing she had waiting for me.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: In here, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Hello, baby. Anybody else in the house?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Nobody. Why?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: What's that music?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: A radio up the street.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Just like the first time I was here. We were talking about automobile insurance. Only you were thinking about murder. And I was thinking about that anklet.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: And what are you thinking about now?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I'm all through thinking. This is goodbye.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Goodbye? Where are you going?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It's you that's going, baby. Not me. I'm getting off the trolley car right at this corner.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Suppose you stop being fancy. Let's have it, whatever it is.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: I have a friend who's got a funny theory. He says when two people commit a murder they're kind of on a trolley car, and one can't get off without the other. They're stuck with each other. They have to go on riding clear to the end of the line. And the last stop is the cemetery.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Maybe he's got something there.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You bet he has, Two people are going to ride to the end of the line, all right. Only I'm not going to be one of them. I've got another guy to finish my ride for me.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: So you've got it all arranged, Walter.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: You arranged it for me. I didn't have to do a thing.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Just who are you talking about?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: An acquaintance of yours. A Mr. Zachetti. Come on, baby, I just got into this because I knew a little something about insurance, didn't I? I was just a sucker. I'd have been brushed-off as soon as you got your hands on the money.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Save it. I'm telling this. It's been you and that Zachetti guy all along, hasn't it?

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: That's not true.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: It doesn't make any difference whether it's true or not. The point is Keyes believes Zachetti is the guy he's been looking for. He'll have him in that gas chamber before he knows what happened to him.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: And what's happening to me all this time?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Don't be silly. What do you expect to happen to you? You helped him do the murder, didn't you? That's what Keyes thinks. And what's good enough for Keyes is good enough for me.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Maybe it's not good enough for me. Walter. Maybe I don't go for the idea. Maybe I'd rather talk.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Sometimes people are where they can't talk. Under six feet of dirt, for instance. And if it was you, they'd just charge it up to Zachetti, wouldn't they. One more item on his account. Sure they would. That's just what they're going to do. Especially since he's coming here, tonight... Oh, in about fifteen minutes from now, baby. With the cops right behind him. It's all taken care of.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: And that'd make everything lovely for you, wouldn't it?

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: Right. And it's got to be done before that suit of yours comes to trial, and Lola gets a chance to sound off, and they trip you up on the stand, and you start to fold up and drag me down with you.

Speaker: phyllis
Dialogue: Listen, Walter. Maybe I had Zachetti here so they won't get a chance to trip me up. So we can get that money and be together.

Speaker: neff
Dialogue: That's cute. Say it again.
